case_name: Plaintiff v. ex-Ruler of Jaipur State, Military Secretary and Mohabat Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 20 of 1960 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 20 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 5, 1956, of the Judicial Commissioners Court at Ajmer in Civil First Appeal No. 3 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 5, 1956 of Judicial Commissioners Court at Ajmer in Civil First Appeal No. 3 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 5, 1956, of the Judicial Commissioners Court at Ajmer in Civil First Appeal No. 3 of 1956. D. Sharma, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 3, 1961 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J. - This is an appeal by the,, plaintiff against the judgment and decree of the Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer, companyfirming the decree of the trail Judge dismissing the suit.

facts.text: Suit filed by appellant for recovery of Rs. 23,998-12-0 as price of goods supplied in 1947 to Ruler of Jaipur State, including interest and damages due to refusal to take delivery of other goods.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed by the appellant for recovery of Rs. 23,998-12-0 as price of goods supplied in the year 1947 to the Ruler of Jaipur State, including interest  and damages suffered by the appellant due to the refusal of the defendants to take delivery of some other goods similarly ordered.

facts.text: Suit filed on February 28, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was filed on February 28, 1951. The ex-Ruler raised the plea that the suit was incompetent, as the companysent of the Central Government under s. 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure was number obtained and asked that the suit be dismissed.

facts.text: Defendants joined: ex-Ruler of Jaipur, Military Secretary, Mohabat Singh as agents of ex-Ruler.

anchor.surface_text: In addition to the ex-Ruler of Jaipur, his Military Secretary and one Mohabat Singh, an employee of the ex-Ruler, were also joined as defendants, on the plea that they had placed the orders as agents of, the ex-Ruler.

facts.text: ex-Ruler raised plea that suit incompetent without consent of Central Government under s.87B CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The ex-Ruler raised the plea that the suit was incompetent, as the companysent of the Central Government under s. 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure was number obtained and asked that the suit be dismissed.

facts.text: Military Secretary (second defendant) has died, appeal not directed against him.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned the Military Secretary  second defendant  has since died, and this appeal is number directed against the ex-Ruler and Mohabat Singh only.

facts.text: Suit filed prior to enactment of s.87B by s.12 of CPC Amendment Act 11 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held that though the suit was filed prior to the enactment of s. 87-B by s. 12 of the Code of Civil Procedure  Amendment  Act, 1951  11 of 1951 ,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held suit cannot be continued against ex-Ruler without consent, adjourned hearing for four months.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held that though the suit was filed prior to the enactment of s. 87-B by s. 12 of the Code of Civil Procedure  Amendment  Act, 1951  11 of 1951 , it companyld number be companytinued against the ex-Ruler.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Central Government for consent, but refused.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant applied to the Central Government for its companysent, but it was refused.

facts.text: Appellant applied in revision to Judicial Commissioner contending s.87B offends Art.14, rejected.

anchor.surface_text: He also applied in revision to the Judicial Commissioner, companytending that s. 87-B of the. Code of Civil Procedure offended the equality clause in Art. 14 of the Constitution and was thus void, but the Judicial Commissioner rejected the companytention.

facts.text: Suit dismissed against all three defendants by Subordinate Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was subsequently dismissed against all the three defendants. In regard to the ex- Ruler, it was held that numbersuit lay against him without the companysent of the Central Government,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held other defendants protected by s.230 Indian Contract Act, s.230(3) inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: and in regard to the remaining defendants, it was held that they were protected by s. 230 of the Indian Contract Act. Sub-section  3  of that section was held inapplicable, inasmuch as a suit companyld be filed against the ex-Ruler with the companysent of the Central Government.

facts.text: Appeal to Judicial Commissioner Ajmer dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant appealed to the Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer, but the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: Certificate under Arts.132(1) and 133(1)(c) granted by High Court of Rajasthan after Reorganisation of States.

anchor.surface_text: it companyes before us on a certificate under Arts. 132 1  and 133 1  c  of the Constitution granted by the High Court of Rajasthan after the Reorganisatiion of the States.

facts.text: Petitioner contends s.87B ultra vires Art.14.

anchor.surface_text: The first is that the dismissal of the suit against the ex-Ruler was erroneous. In support of this companytention, it is urged that s. 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure is ultra vires the Constitution in view of Art. 14,

facts.text: Petitioner contends alternatively s.87B does not apply to pending suit.

anchor.surface_text: and, in the alternative, that s. 87-B, even if valid, cannot apply to this suit, which was pending when the section was enacted. The right to companytinue the suit being a substantive right,

facts.text: Petitioner contends Mohabat Singh liable as agent or sub-agent under s.230(3) Indian Contract Act.

anchor.surface_text: Against the other respondent, it is companytended that he was liable as an agent or at least, as sub-agent, in view of the provisions of s. 230 3  of the Indian Contract Act.

facts.text: Court held s.87B not ultra vires, applies to pending suits.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the words personal rights and privileges are sufficiently companyprehensive to embrace an immunity of this character. It is, therefore, clear that the section cannot be challenged as discriminatory, because it arises from a classification based on historical facts.

facts.text: Mohabat Singh signed letters for Military Secretary, not agent of ex-Ruler.

anchor.surface_text: Mohabat Singh, who is the third defendant, cannot be described as an agent of the ex-Ruler, because his companynection with the orders placed was merely to sign the letters purporting to emanate from the Military Secretary.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the dismissal of the suit was justified in the circumstances of the case. The appeal fails, and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Rulers of Indian States integrated with British India via covenants assuring privileges.

anchor.surface_text: When the Indian States integrated with British India, the Rulers of States and the Government of India entered Into companyenants and agreements. In those companyenants, it was agreed that the privileges, dignities and titles of the Indian Princes would be companytinued to be recognised.

anchor.surface_text: When the Constitution was enacted, the assurance in the companyenants was respected, and Art. 362 was included in the Constitution. It reads In the exercise of the power of Parliament or of the Legislature of a State to make laws or in the exercise of the executive power of the Union or of a State, due regard shall be had to the guarantee or assurance given under any such companyenant or agreement as is referred to in clause  i  of Article 291 with respect to the personal rights, privileges and dignities of the Ruler of an Indian State.

concepts.interpretation: Mandates due regard to covenants assuring personal rights, privileges, dignities of ex-Rulers, including immunity from suit.

anchor.surface_text: Section 86 provided for suits against Princes, Chiefs, Ambassadors and Envoys. It created partial ex-territoriality by granting them exemption from civil jurisdiction except when an action was brought with the companysent of the Central Government. The first sub-section provided- Any such Prince or Chief, and any ambassador or envoy of a foreign State, may in the case of the Ruling Chief of an Indian State with the companysent of the Crown Representative, certified by the signature of the Political Secretary, and in any other case with the companysent of the Central Government, certified by the signature of a secretary to that Government, but number without such companysent, be sued in any companypetent Court.

concepts.interpretation: Provides consent requirement for suing foreign Rulers; extended to ex-Indian Rulers via s.87B; 'sued' covers continuation of pending suits.

issues.text: Whether s. 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure is ultra vires the Constitution in view of Art. 14?

anchor.surface_text: contention, it is urged that s. 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure is ultra vires the Constitution in view of Art. 14, and, in the alternative, that s. 87-B, even if valid, cannot apply to this suit, which was pending when the section was enacted.

issues.text: Whether s. 87-B applies to suits pending when the section was enacted, or whether the right to continue such a suit is a substantive right that cannot be taken away without express language or necessary intendment?

anchor.surface_text: and, in the alternative, that s. 87-B, even if valid, cannot apply to this suit, which was pending when the section was enacted. The right to continue the suit being a substantive right, cannot, it is submitted, be taken away except by a law which is made applicable to pending actions, either expressly or by necessary intendment.

issues.text: Whether the other respondent (Mohabat Singh) was liable as an agent or sub-agent under s. 230(3) of the Indian Contract Act?

anchor.surface_text: Against the other respondent, it is contended that he was liable as an agent or at least, as sub-agent, in view of the provisions of s. 230 3 of the Indian Contract Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rejected by Judicial Commissioner and upheld by SC on classification grounds

arguments.claim: Ex-Rulers form a distinct class based on historical covenants justifying special treatment under s.87-B; not discriminatory under Art.14

anchor.surface_text: It is easy to see that the ex-Rulers form a class and the special legislation is based upon historical companysiderations applicable to them as a class. The Princes who were, before integration, sovereign Rulers of Indian States, handed over, after the foundation of the Republic, their States to the Nation in return for an annual Privy Purse and the assurance that their personal rights, privileges and dignities would be respected.

arguments.claim: Personal rights and privileges under Art.362 include immunity from suit

anchor.surface_text: It is further companytended that the Article speaks of privileges but number of immunities... Immunity from civil action may be described also as a privilege, because the word Privilege is sufficiently wide to include an immunity.

arguments.claim: "Sued" in s.86/87B includes continuation of pending suits, not just initiation

anchor.surface_text: The word sued means number only the filing of a suit or a civil proceeding but also their pursuit through Courts. A person is sued number only when the plaint is filed, but is sued also when the suit remains pending against him.

arguments.claim: Mohabat Singh not agent of ex-Ruler, merely signed letters for Military Secretary

anchor.surface_text: Mohabat Singh, who is the third defendant, cannot be described as an agent of the ex-Ruler, because his companynection with the orders placed was merely to sign the letters purporting to emanate from the Military Secretary.

holdings.text: Section 87-B of the Code of Civil Procedure is not ultra vires Article 14 of the Constitution as it arises from a reasonable classification of ex-Rulers based on historical facts and covenants assuring their personal rights, privileges and dignities.

anchor.surface_text: It is further contended that the Article speaks of privileges but not of immunities... Immunity from civil action may be described also as a privilege, because the word Privilege is sufficiently wide to include an immunity. In our opinion, the words personal rights and privileges are sufficiently comprehensive to embrace an immunity of this character. It is, therefore, clear that the section cannot be challenged as discriminatory, because it arises from a classification based on historical facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex-Rulers form a distinct class due to integration covenants; classification real, substantial, rationally related to object of preserving privileges under Art. 362; 'privileges' includes immunity from suit.

holdings.text: Section 87-B applies to suits pending at the time of its enactment; the word 'sued' encompasses not only initiation but also continuation of suits.

anchor.surface_text: The word sued means not only the filing of a suit or a civil proceeding but also their pursuit through Courts. A person is sued not only when the plaint is filed, but is sued also when the suit remains pending against him. The word sued covers the entire proceeding in an action, and the person proceeded against is sued throughout the duration of the action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'sued' in s.86(1) as applied by s.87-B includes pursuit and continuation of pending actions; no saving for pending suits; language rebuts presumption against retrospectivity.

holdings.text: The present suit was incompetent against the ex-Ruler of Jaipur without consent of the Central Government under s.87-B.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, the present suit was incompetent against the first defendant, the ex-Ruler of Jaipur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines validity and applicability of s.87-B to pending suit; consent required for continuation against ex-Ruler.

holdings.text: Mohabat Singh is not liable as an agent or sub-agent of the ex-Ruler under s.230(3) of the Indian Contract Act; his role was merely signing letters for the Military Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: Mohabat Singh, who is the third defendant, cannot be described as an agent of the ex-Ruler, because his connection with the orders placed was merely to sign the letters purporting to emanate from the Military Secretary. Those letters he signed for the Military Secretary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual finding: connection limited to ministerial act of signing for Military Secretary, not constituting agency for ex-Ruler; suit misconceived.

holdings.text: The dismissal of the suit by lower courts was justified; appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the dismissal of the suit was justified in the circumstances of the case. The appeal fails, and is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; holdings on s.87-B and agency support upholding dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: It is further contended that the Article speaks of privileges but not of immunities... Immunity from civil action may be described also as a privilege, because the word Privilege is sufficiently wide to include an immunity. In our opinion, the words personal rights and privileges are sufficiently comprehensive to embrace an immunity of this character. It is, therefore, clear that the section cannot be challenged as discriminatory, because it arises from a classification based on historical facts.
The appeal fails, and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The word sued means not only the filing of a suit or a civil proceeding but also their pursuit through Courts. A person is sued not only when the plaint is filed, but is sued also when the suit remains pending against him. The word sued covers the entire proceeding in an action, and the person proceeded against is sued throughout the duration of the action.
The appeal fails, and is dismissed with costs.
